Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>SharpNEAT looks like it's starting to work really well, and the 
>simulations are great.
>
Yep, cheers. Starting to get some nice results now.  Actually I was just 
looking at Mattias' pole balancing demo - on the DelphiNEAT web site 
Mattias mentions poor performance on this problem as well. Mattias, did 
you ever resolve this problem? Could this be because of the initial 
population that you are using?

>  What is the fitness function being used in 
>the no wiggle pole balancing?  Is it the Gruau one used in our 
>paper?  Because the fitness numbers I'm seeing don't look familiar 
>to me in that experiment.
>  
>
Yes I tried to set it up as described in the paper, except I am not 
performing the generalization tests on the generation champion. Are the 
generalization tests reflected in the fitness score?

What I normally see is the fitness rising to between 10.0 and 10.09. 
This corresponds with a network that has run the full 100000 timesteps 
since the f1 fitness component comes to [((100000 / 1000) * 0.1)=10  ] 
but the f2 component=0.0 to 0.09 due to wiggling.  Perhaps it's the 
initial pop again - if it is more conducive to generating wiggling 
solutions then f1 will quickly rise, once this happens you are unlikely 
to find non-wiggling solutions from a population of wiggling ones, the 
search is stuck in a local maximum.

Or maybe it the lack of generalization tests is keeping poor solutions 
in the population tat otherwise would have been culled?

Colin
